> I would like to be able to find out which tests that have stopped 
> working between two of our nightly builds (which run a set of JUnit 
> tests). Since we currently have more than 500 test cases it is 
> difficult to do this manually. It would of course be easy if the 
> normal success rate was 100%, but a number of test cases fail since 
> the implementation is not yet completed.

Funny I discussed that with Bill Venners a few days ago.

Your problem is that not all of your tests pass.  So my question is: how can a
developer be sure that he didn't introduce a bug with some new code?  X tests
were failing before the modification and now Y tests are failing.  If Y>X you
don't know which one is/are now failing.

IMO opinion (and in your case) you have two kinds of failing tests:
- the one that shouldn't
- the one that will, and it's ok (testing not implemented features, not
implemented tests)

JUnit doesn't directly give you the possibility to separate the "good" from the
"bad" failing tests.  You have to come up with your own solution.

What I would do:
- rename the tests that should fail testXYZ_failing
- rewrite some JUnit components (it depends what kind of runner you're using
(ant, swing, textui) to filter these tests
- or write an XSLT file to process the XML and remove the '_failing' methods
from the report

-Vladimir
